You taught your people, whom God entrusted you with, and confirmed them in the true orthodox faith. You brought them from outside darkness to the true light, and taught them to worship the co-essential Trinity. You also baptized them, from their youngest to their oldest, in the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit, and fed them with the life-giving manna that came down from heaven, that is, the true Body of Christ and His Blood. Jason the celibate, truly blessed are you, for you rejoiced with Christ in the kingdom of heaven.

When Queen Helen arrested all the Jews and said: "Death and life is before you, inform me of the place of the Cross." The queen ordered he be thrown into a cave, and she left him without food or drink until he informed her of the place of the cross. His compassionate acts extended to the poor and weak, from the first day of his bishopric to the day of his repose, such that no money was left. And you rejoiced with the saints, and with Christ, whom you loved, in the heavenly Jerusalem forever and ever.

Therefore, I cry in fear, saying: "Coach me to come to you upon the water, that is, the rivers of the waters of life which run from your lips, and which give drink to the people of the world." She whose father Mark loved, who became an elect martyr because of her. Her parents were Christians, and her father was a governor of Borollus. He built a great palace for his daughter and decorated it with every kind (of decoration). She took it as a place of prayer, and for the holy worship of the true God. Forty virgins lived with her; they were blessed and pure. The Lord said, through the mouth of David, the pure heavenly psalmist: "How good and sweet when the brethren live together." This, St.Â Demiana, together with the virgins, fulfilled with great struggle. During the time of persecution, her father denied Christ Jesus. His wise daughter St.Â Demiana restored him to the orthodox faith. When Diocletian heard of this, he was angry and severed his head, and he wore the crown of martyrdom and rejoiced with the saints and faithful. The idolater king also ordered they torture her until they kill her. She suffered may toils and tortures along with the forty virgins who were with her. They gave up their souls willingly in the name of Christ, and accepted the suffering of torture because of their love for His name. St.Â Demiana urged them to stay steadfast in the orthodox faith in Jesus Christ. In the end, their heads were severed and they wore the crown of martyrdom.

There was a rich man, one of the eminent personalities named Mark. He was a governor of Borollus. God gave him this pure girl, Demiana. She was the beloved of both her parents. They baptized her a Christian and taught her to read the Holy Scriptures. When she turned fifteen years old, her father wanted her to marry. She said to him: "Father, do not think about my marriage, for I devoted myself as a bride for Jesus Christ. I ask you for something. I ask you to build me a palace, to stay in it and worship my Master and God, Christ." Her father answered her request, and was very glad with what she said. He built her a great palace and decorated it with every kind (of decoration). When she, the elect lady, Demiana, entered the palace she took with her forty virgins, daughters of preeminent people, they were always her companions in reading, praying, and going to church, at dawn and at dusk. When Diocletian became an idolater and rejected the worship of the Lord God, he ordered the deputies and governors to worship the defiled idols. Among them was St.Â Mark. He obeyed the king and worshiped the idols with them. When the news reached Demiana, his daughter, the faithful nun, she was shocked and very saddened. She went to him in Farama. She restored her father to the faith, in which his heart was confirmed, and he regretted what he did. He gathered his mental strength, returned to Diocletian, and confessed before him (his faith) in our Lord, Jesus Christ. The king wrote his judgment, and his head was taken by the stroke of the sword. He became a chosen martyr, supplicating on behalf of the sinners and received the crown of martyrdom. When the king learned that pure St.Â Demiana was the one who encouraged her father to disobey him, he was instantly filled with great anger and ordered she be tortured until death, both she and those who were with her. The deputy met her and informed her, saying: "My master the king orders you to worship his gods." The saint was angry and said to him: "Cursed is the messenger and he who sent him. No god is worshiped in heaven or on earth, except Jesus Christ, the Word, the eternal creator. As for me, I confess (my faith) in the life-giving Holy Trinity, the Father, the Son the Savior, and the Holy Spirit, the Paraclete. In him I confess, on Him I depend and in His name I die and with Him I live forever." Then, the hypocrite deputy was full of anger. He took her outside the palace, and decreed her torture. She bravely tolerated the scourging. He cut her tongue, but she did not yield ever. She received grave tortures. She gave over her soul to death and her body to the fire. Thus she crushed the power of the enemy. At the end of this exalted struggle, her head was taken by the stroke of the sword, and she received the incorruptible crown in the kingdom of heaven, along with the forty saintly virgins who were with her in the palace. They received martyrdom on the same day. On the thirteenth of Tobe this saint was martyred. And on the twelfth day of Pashons, a church was consecrated in her name.

You who taught us the perfect worship to the Holy Trinity, one, undivided. The hosts of heaven and the ranks of saints are proud of your purity and virtuous struggle. We ask you pure virgin, to supplicate on our behalf before Christ, whom you loved, to grant us His peace and His mercy and the forgiveness of our sins.

What corporeal tongue could speak of their honor, for they were worthy to behold the Lord, and He blessed them both. They completed their seeking with toils, suffering, and great ascetics in worship. As for St.Â George, he became sick for a few days. When our Savior willed to take him from this age, he surrendered his spirit into the hands of Jesus Christ, and was reposed with the saints in the region of the living.
